Meanwhile: could you explain a little bit more on The use case of this interface? I'm thinking maybe similar information could be simply obtained by chaining the data iter with the python enumerate function. Also other data iter needs to be modified to add the same interface.

Thanks for the contribution. I have made a few comments on the code, in general
- Code Style, we use Google C++ code style, you can reproduce the linter check locally using

```
make lint
```
- [ ] Try to use standard functions when possible
  - This include std::swap and std::accumulate
- [ ] DeclareBackwardDependency, as Backward only depend on out_grad
  - c.f. http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/developer-guide/operator.html
- [ ] Please also write a testcase in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/tests/python/unittest/test_operator.py

I think what was wanted is because each image have a unique index, so we can use it to remap labels. Say we store the imid -> bounding box in an independent map on python, and want to attach that information to the iter, while still being able to use the preproc pipeline
I see. Thanks!
I think if you write an adapter to implement the DataIter, things might work out of the box
@antinucleon Can you review it and merge if you think it is good to go?
Thanks for contribution, I have added your name to https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/CONTRIBUTORS.md , please feel free to add more detail about you, or help the community to improve mxnet.

Thanks for the suggestion. Most examples are too heavily weighted, to be added to the testcase. But you are right that we need to be more careful about examples when API changes are introduced. 

Most API should be stablized and we would expect a few changes in IO to make it more general, hopefully such thing will happen less in the future
Closing for now, please feel free to re-open, seems to be problem of not installing BLAS
closing for now as answered in last comment, please feel free to reopen

This is a bug due to recent dataiterator interface change.
Will be fixed after https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/505 is merged
lgtm, Thanks for contribution!

The lr_mult is a bit debatable. A better way might be setup per index lr into optimizer. Can you remove the lr_mult for now. The rest of example looks good to me. Please add a README.md to guide user on   how to run examples.

+1 for the task based examples.

I think it is fine to do examples as PR, because they are real contributions and we like to give credit our contributors that.

I think we can have both: an in house example repo, plus an exmaple registry, where people can freely post their work with mxnet.

For example a researcher published a paper that uses mxnet, he/she may want to manage their own repo and don't like submitting PR for every change, but also want other mxnet users to be able to find his/her work

I like the idea of example registry. 

It can either be a README.md(with links to people's repo) or wiki.
wiki sounds better. The idea is to minimize the effort it takes to register a work
the example depends on it. we can merge this after we have a solution

Please review and merge it. I added a simple cache for the first batch to avoid calling reset. The discussed simplification of base iter interface could wait later, otherwise accumulating conflicts with base could get quite complicated. I hope I did not overwrite something during merging.
Thanks very much for your suggestions.

I have one comment on support epoch_size parameter which is added by @mli for distributed training. Maybe need to add that back.

This is used when different machines have different batches on their local data, and we need to make sure each machine run the same number of batches in one epoch in distributed setting. Otherwise one machine will run additional batch, and hang because other machine did not send statistics over in BSP setting
Other parts LGTM
As discussed, let us consider move the lr scaling to the optimizer
I tried to recover that part here.

There are two ways:
1. write an operator with cuda kernel under src/operator. You get best performance but need to put in some effort.
2. write an operator in python with numpy using https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/436. It's fast to develop but may become performance bottleneck. See examples/numpy-op/numpy_softmax.py.
cool, this is merged

thanks for your reply!

Fast and Faster R-CNN's changes to Caffe are all in [this commit](https://github.com/rbgirshick/caffe-fast-rcnn/commit/4115385deb3b907fcd428ac0ab53b694d741a3c4) and the object detection application is [here](https://github.com/rbgirshick/py-faster-rcnn).

```
Fast and Faster R-CNN change set
 - smooth l1 loss
 - roi pooling
 - expose phase in pycaffe
 - dropout scaling at test time (needed for MSRA-trained ZF network)
```
It's best to have a fine-tuning example https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/379 in the style of [this doc](http://caffe.berkeleyvision.org/gathered/examples/finetune_flickr_style.html).

Cherrypy is only suitable for very small projects. Flask is a much more powerful and popular light weight web framework. Uber developed its RESTful web service framework [Clay](https://github.com/uber/clay) based on Flask. The [hello world example](http://clayframework.com/) is extremely simple.

``` python
from __future__ import absolute_import
from clay import app

@app.route('/', methods=['GET'])
def hello():
    '''
    Ensures that the world is still there.
    '''
    return 'Hello World!'
```

Alibaba's cloud computing service [Aliyun](http://www.aliyun.com/) is offering price-off promotions right now as a part of the 11.11 global shopping festival.

also agree that we can reorg the example by applications. it would be even better if each examples supports tags. for example, for the imagnet inception examples, we can have

```
# tags: ilsvrc12, inception, batch-normalization, convolution
```

and them build a tag index automatically. so people who are interested on dn technologies can find the examples quickly

Search would be good. 
The docker registry model looks pretty nice. Is there a solution for building something like that easily?

do you mean a docker hub like service to host pre-trained models? probably putting a model in a downloadable place is good enough. if we use docker, we often link the model into docker, rather than make the model into the docker image, which will result in frequent building.

if you mean the tag search, probably a simple grep script will do the trick. we already did that in the dmlc blog, see
https://github.com/dmlc/dmlc.github.io/blob/master/_posts/2015-11-03-training-deep-net-with-R.markdown

I think a custom metric that saves when update is called is a good way to
go.
Python/mxnet/metric

I'm not quite sure how the environment is set up. It's possible you are not linked against pthread. Make sure you have `-pthreads` in the compile options.
Can you do this directly in R? @hetong007
You can do that using batch.end.callback, which takes current environment as arguments, and you can create a closure to save things you want
@junranhe  #468 is merged, can you rebase and update this PR? Thanks
@pommedeterresautee Any updates on this? I will merge this after the html file get removed

Yes, the idea is to add operations as we need and make it easier to do so. 
- Currently, there is a PythonOp that allows you to directly write operator in python(i.e. all numpy).
- More optimized operator can be added from c++ side, using mshadow, with no knowledge of GPU programming.

So either you can quickly hack up what you need using numpy, or add important ops in c++ as we need to add them(open up issues on what we want and we can discuss how it can be added)

We are also continuing to enhance the interface to make adding new operations easier than the current way.
May I ask are there any examples on how to hack with PythonOp for some numpy like operations?

Yes here it is https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/numpy-ops

Please also feel free to open issue for specific Op you want as you encounter problems, we can discuss more in detail on how things can be added :) Most of which should be pretty straight forward
@piiswrong I think we want to highlight NumpyOp somewhere in the doc(maybe python/index.md), can you open a PR for this?
many thanks!
It is not possible, I compiled the mxnet without changing anything.Just used default setting.

I think we need to few HOWTO pages and link them in the root README
1) How to create new operators (c++ and numpy)
2) How to write custom training loop

I come across a problem:
`SwapAxis(..., dim1=2, dim2=3)`can work well on both cpu and gpu.
`SwapAxis(..., dim1=3, dim2=2)`only work well on cpu, but fail on gpu with the following error:

```
INFO:root:Start training with [gpu(0)]
[13:46:12] ./dmlc-core/include/dmlc/logging.h:208: [13:46:12] ./mshadow/mshadow/./tensor_blob.h:530: Check failed: (this->shape_.Size()) == (shape.Size()) TBlob.get_with_shape: new and old shape do not match total elements
[13:46:12] ./dmlc-core/include/dmlc/logging.h:208: [13:46:12] src/engine/./threaded_engine.h:295: [13:46:12] ./mshadow/mshadow/./tensor_blob.h:530: Check failed: (this->shape_.Size()) == (shape.Size()) TBlob.get_with_shape: new and old shape do not match total elements
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'dmlc::Error'
  what():  [13:46:12] src/engine/./threaded_engine.h:295: [13:46:12] ./mshadow/mshadow/./tensor_blob.h:530: Check failed: (this->shape_.Size()) == (shape.Size()) TBlob.get_with_shape: new and old shape do not match total elements
Aborted (core dumped)
```

@hetong007 Let us add it as a batch.end.callback function
std::accumulate can not be recognized by nvcc.
I think this PR is good to go. Just suggest change lr_mult to `lr_scale`, which seems to be more clear
Oh, yap. Maybe create our own version of prod function is easier. Then I think it is OK. Thanks
For the error, as it indicates, it means the shape's size do not match the size of TBlob. Likely due to shape initialization error, either InferShape or Shape2Five
The platform dependency issue was likely due to some uninitialized memory(variable) that causes uncertainties, but just my guess
Also convention issue in python3, dict.get should not use keyword argument, but simply get(index, 1.0)
I recompiled the all, removed the std::accumulate, and then the problem of `dim1=3, dim2=2` of gpu is gone...............


If the testcase pass, I will do another round of code review. Thanks!
I have no cpplint module.

You can insall cpplint and pylint by 

```
pip install cpplint pylint
```

can you help me for the following problem?

``` python
def test2():
    data_in = mx.symbol.Variable('data')
    conv = mx.symbol.Convolution(data=data_in, kernel=(3, 3), num_filter=16)
    datatmp = np.ones((1, 1, 32, 64))
    mxdata = mx.nd.array(datatmp)
    weightmp = np.ones((16, 1, 3, 3))
    mxweight = mx.nd.array(weightmp)
    biastmp = np.zeros(16)
    mxbias = mx.nd.array(biastmp)
    exe_c = conv.bind(ctx=mx.gpu(0), args=[mxdata, mxweight, mxbias])
    out = exe_c.forward()
    print out

test2()
```

Error

```
None
[[14:29:51] ./dmlc-core/include/dmlc/logging.h:208: [14:29:51] ./mshadow/mshadow/./stream_gpu-inl.h:98: Check failed: (err) == (CUBLAS_STATUS_SUCCESS) Create cublas handle failed
14:29:51] ./dmlc-core/include/dmlc/logging.h:208: [14:29:51] ./mshadow/mshadow/./stream_gpu-inl.h:98: Check failed: (err) == (CUBLAS_STATUS_SUCCESS) Create cublas handle failed
terminate called recursively
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'Aborted (core dumped)
```

what's the next step?

```
=====69/70 cpp-header files passed check=====
src/operator/swapaxis-inl.h: 34 Errors of 4 Categories map={'whitespace': 29, 'runtime': 2, 'readability': 2, 'build': 1}
=====57/58 cpp-soruce files passed check=====
src/operator/swapaxis.cc: 2 Errors of 1 Categories map={'readability': 2}
```
resolve all the comments by cpplint, there are detailed messages

For output, we need to do

```
exec_c.forward()
out = exec.output[0].asnumpy()
print out
```

The error was due to we did not call asnumpy to wait for the result, and the system start to shutdown before the computation starts.
I can see nothing comments in the swapaxis files by cpplint? where are they?

cpu is work right now, but not for gpu:

``` python
def test2():
    data_in = mx.symbol.Variable('data')
    conv = mx.symbol.Convolution(data=data_in, kernel=(3, 3), num_filter=16)
    datatmp = np.ones((1, 1, 32, 64))
    mxdata = mx.nd.array(datatmp)
    weightmp = np.ones((16, 1, 3, 3))
    mxweight = mx.nd.array(weightmp)
    biastmp = np.zeros(16)
    mxbias = mx.nd.array(biastmp)
    exe_c = conv.bind(ctx=mx.gpu(0), args=[mxdata, mxweight, mxbias])
    exe_c.forward()
    out = exe_c.outputs[0].asnumpy()
    print out

test2()
```

Error

```
[14:50:16] ./dmlc-core/include/dmlc/logging.h:208: [14:50:16] ./mshadow/mshadow/./tensor_blob.h:508: Check failed: Device::kDevMask == dev_mask_ && DataType<DType>::kFlag == type_flag_ TBlob.get: device type do not match specified type
```

Thanks for the good job! I have last few comments, please address them and rebase to resolve the conflict to current master here.

http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/contribute.html#how-to-resolve-conflict-with-master

The conflict might have something to do with commits you have in mshadow, if that is the case, the best way might be reset mshadow's version, or keep a copy of your files, and do a clean fork

Actually, what I mean by ScalarOp was ElementwiseBinaryScalarOp. Something like AddSymbolScalar, MinusSymbolScalar. So the operator can pass shape inference check, and we do not need to create a real NDArray for the scalars
Thanks for the details, please also mention mshadow, as most operators don't need knowledge of CUDA. Add a link to this tutorial from the main docs including python/index.md and index.md
@tqchen I know
Done, please have a check!
